positive.review: Really fun but needs more class balancing and more content, PVP is very difficult but feels rewarding to learn, bossfights are a pain but are also a fun challenge.
Despite the controversy and mixed reception, it’s genuinely fun. The blend of dungeon crawling, tense extraction mechanics, and gritty fantasy makes each run thrilling.

This game is improving. From my understanding, the dev team had an idea for what the game should be, and the experience didn't coincide with the experience that the players were getting. While I do enjoy this, there are definitely areas for improvement. at the moment, the combat feels quite lack-lustre at times. A dodging or parrying mechanic would be fun. I have played a mix of solo PVE and solo/group PVP at the moment, and both game modes have their positives and negatives. The PVP has a obvious issue with certain classes being stronger than others. I like to play as a barbarian, and because of this, I often found myself struggling to combat archers and mages. slow moving mechanics of the melee units mean that without throwables, you become a pincushion - unable to catch up with the high dex archers, and unable to escape as they can hound you down and engage at a distance (skill issue for sure, but not without balancing concerns). 

While I agree with this as an experience in theory, it ends up being a little un-fun, especially given that you can only have one character slot if you don't purchase the premium upgrade for your account.

In regards to PVE, while I enjoy the more casual experience of hacking my way through various creepy-crawlies, the lack of combat mechanics means that the fights become repetitive. I feel like with the addition of a parry mechanic for all weapon types, and potentially a dodge mechanic, the combat could become a little more skill based/fluid - just improving upon the experience in general.

Overall, I feel like this game has a massive amount of potential, and if the dev team continues in the vein that they currently are, there could be some definite growth - especially once they complete the skill system. I'd love to see a DnD inspired skill tree that allows players to improve themselves in an RPG style of function. Fast shooting archers, near bullet proof knights, and devastating mages would be great fun for the game.

I'd personally argue that the PVE experience has the greater potential overall, as it could become a genuinely amazing group based dungeon crawler. Hope to see the game grow and improve in time.

Truthfully, I love the aesthetic. Dark and grimy, DnD feel to it. Overall I enjoy the way it plays out personally but there are some glaring issues that will result in the "mixed" reviews.

One of which being you get a shell of whats offered as a free to play variant, If you want the "full game" experience, with selling on the player market, more than 1 character (ect.)  you have to pay $30. I get the idea of the free to play model, but it almost feels like you should have charged it to begin with because it feels like im being "Lured" into paying the premium price anyways (which I did since Im curious to see where the game develops from here)

New player engagement: Just bang your head against a wall, youll learn not to hit your head cuz it hurts... this game is the same way. You get no info, no guides, and basically learn everything on your own unless you use YT guides or direct over to their discord for help... and lets be honest. For a free to play game, who is going to immediately jump to their discord for a "knight" (a real player designed to help guide people) when they are more inclined to just uninstall it since it didnt cost them money anyways.

Merchants. There is a reputation system to gain "favor". I personally like this but it really just takes experimenting with to figure out the different tabs and what they do. Good amount of choices, but very overwhelming, ESPECIALLY when you dont have a tutorial to explain out the system at all... (refer back to their "knight" program again)

As for combat...? Its unique. I personally like it but it isnt for everyone. Its a little slower and for attacking it relies on the animation, not the reticle. You may think youll hit your target... that is until a wall torch you couldnt see on your screen stops you overhead swing and the enemy gets a free hit on you. Again, its not terrible imo... its just designed with a specific player base in mind.

As for the map for each campaign? If your not gonna give us a tutorial, at least let us have a legend on what symbols mean. Red stairs vs blue stairs. Ropes being only 1 person extract. Or even that damn elevator in the center of the goblin caves... I still cant figure hat one out aside from it just... appears?

Basically, the whole structure revolves around just "winging it and figuring it out" which will drive away a lot of people from a free to play game if they dont have the persistence to learn... and with a game that SEEMS to have ever increasing nuances and things that "just work that way" its hard to understand unless you know the basics of DnD-esque games. 

2 health bar systems, light red, dark red, and empty... each one solved using a different healing item... of which... again... isnt guided to you almost at all.

A prime example is you have to hit G at a campfire. It acts as a "long rest" to give back spell slots. Learned that after a few hours of pain staking failures with my crew only for my ranger to appreciate getting back his healing food ability when we found out about it.

Basically if you want guidance, you wont find it here unless you go out of your way to get it... the community is nice in pve, but you have to ask to even have a chance of learning... if you dont like that, it isnt for you.... thanks for reading this though!

I joined Dark and Darker through a friend who wouldn’t stop talking about it. The name didn’t grab me at first, but once I finally jumped in, I was hooked by the realism. Everything feels grounded — metal armor moves and sounds like metal, lighting is gritty, and every swing in combat actually matters.

You can lose or win a fight with a single mistake or a perfect strike, and that’s part of what makes it so tense and satisfying. The dungeon atmosphere is some of the best I’ve seen, and the visuals and sound design make every run feel dangerous.

That said, I think the game still lacks long-term depth. There’s little immersion or character individuality, and the seasonal wipes make it hard to stay attached to your progress. I’d love to see more customization, persistent world elements, and reasons to keep playing beyond gear resets.

Still, for pure tension, skill-based combat, and atmosphere, Dark and Darker delivers something special. It’s one of the most unique extraction-style dungeon games out there, and if Ironmace builds more world and identity into it, it could become truly legendary.

Dark and Darker is one of those rare games that actually manages to feel unique in today’s landscape. It mixes unforgiving PvE dungeon crawling with tense PvP encounters in a way that constantly keeps you on edge — every step could be your last, every sound could mean danger or treasure.

What really sets it apart for me is the atmosphere. The dark medieval tone, the flickering torches, the sound of footsteps echoing through the halls — it all creates a sense of pressure and immersion that few games pull off this well. The fact that death actually matters makes every run exciting and meaningful.

It’s not a game for everyone; it can be brutal, frustrating, and sometimes unfair. But that’s part of what makes it so rewarding when things finally go your way. Dark and Darker thrives on risk and tension, and if you enjoy that constant push between fear and greed, you’ll love it.

* Load into a dark dungeon
* Fight monsters and other players
* Loot shiny things
* Panic
* Forget where the exit is and die in a circle of fire

It’s like if D&D, Escape from Tarkov, and a renaissance fair all got locked in a basement with permadeath turned on.

---

### Choose Your Class (Choose Your Suffering)

* **Fighter** – Wears all the armor, still dies to one mimic chest
* **Barbarian** – 2 brain cells, 200 damage
* **Rogue** – Steals from enemies, teammates, and your trust
* **Ranger** – Legally an archer, spiritually a camper
* **Wizard** – 3 nukes per dungeon, 40 minutes of stick-bonking after
* **Cleric** – Mobile hospital + emotional support punching bag

You don’t respawn. You don’t get a second chance.
You get **one run**, and then it’s either:

* Escape with loot → god gamer
* Die to a skeleton archer → “unlucky, bad spawn, lag, sun in my eyes, etc.”

---

### Pros

* **Incredible tension.**
  Every footstep behind you is either a goblin, another player…
  or your own teammate breathing directly into their mic.

* Sound design is cruel in the best way:

  * Chainmail rattling
  * Doors creaking
  * Someone opening a chest in the next room and your whole team going full goblin mode: “PUSH THEM.”

* The PvPvE mix is chef’s kiss:

  * You’re mid-fight with three skeletons
  * A rogue appears out of the shadows
  * You die, he teabags, your friends mute their mics because they’re laughing too hard

* When you actually **extract with loot**, it feels better than beating a final boss in most games.

  * “We opened a door and left” somehow = peak victory.

* The jank is part of the charm.
  Your swings are slow, your spells are limited, your vision is trash… and yet you keep queueing.

---

### Cons

* New player experience:

  * Spawn in
  * Open a door
  * Get one-tapped by a trap, a skeleton, a player, or all three
  * Inventory: empty
  * Soul: broken

* If your team dies and you’re last alive, it stops being a game and becomes an anxiety simulator:

  * “Loot their bodies or run?”
  * “Portal or greed?”
  * You pick greed. You die.

* Losing your gear hurts.
  That blue sword you loved? Gone.
  That armor set you farmed all night? Also gone.
  But don’t worry, you still have sandals.

* Solo queue is basically:

  * 30% rat gameplay
  * 30% running from 3-man parties
  * 40% listening for footsteps and regretting having any valuables

---

### Peak Dark and Darker Moments

* Barbarian teammate:

  > “I hear someone, I’m pushing.”
  > *5 seconds later he’s dead in a hallway full of traps and we’re all looting his pockets before reviving him.*

* Rogue loots your body **before** trying to res you.

  * “Just holding your stuff for you, bro.”
  * You don’t get out. He keeps your stuff.

* Opening a chest and getting smacked by a mimic so hard you physically lean back IRL.

* Standing in a tiny room, portal ticking down, red zone closing in, everyone screaming:

  * “YOU TAKE THAT ONE!”
  * “NO, YOU GO!”
  * *Wizard takes both, leaves party to die, says ‘my bad’ in Discord.*

* Escaping with 2 HP, 1 potion, and a backpack full of trash loot that you will proudly overprice on the market.

---

### Final Verdict

Dark and Darker is:

* 30% medieval looter
* 30% horror game
* 40% voice chat panic

It’s brutal, clunky, janky, unfair… and unreasonably addictive.

**9/10**
Would once again spawn with starter gear, die to a skeleton two rooms in, blame “desync,” and queue immediately for another emotionally damaging run.
This game is fun but takes a lot of time moving forward.

Fast paced, skill required, fantasy pvpve action packed goodness. 

Good luck out there!

This game actually sucks, now wtf. I played it for around 100 hours before the lawsuit and it was great. Challenging and fair. Now it's just shit. Every room is pitch black except for a single lit torch that covers 2 inches, enemies no longer miss as they have absurd tracking, the corridors are too tight to strafe around (not that it matters because the tracking is fucked and strafing gets you hit anyways, if you don't have a shield you just take damage no matter what), and I genuinely see no reason for anybody to try picking this game up or re-picking it up if they thought about it again.

I don't see how a game that was nearly perfect before, just needing a couple balance changes and a new map, got turned into this monstrosity that doesn't want you to play it.

I'll paint you a picture of how this game worked when it first released. You woke up in a room with a closed door and a bit of loot in it. When you walked out you would be in a hallway with a single patrolling skeleton. It had either a bow, a sword and shield, or a greatsword. When it started it's attack animation, you could backup or strafe depending on what the animation was, and avoid the attack. The skeleton didn't turn or move forward in order to guarantee an attack. The corridor was also wide enough to allow you to strafe sideways.

Now i'll paint you a picture of the current iteration of this. You wake up in a tight hallway that is only wide enough for 1 person to pass through. There's 18 skeletons in this hallway and 1 will immediately aggro onto you when you spawn in. You can't avoid it's attacks, you can't run away from it as you'll just aggro the next skeleton, and you can't kill it before it blows through 90% of your health. You can try to sit and rest up for the next fight, but the patrolling skeleton has already aggro'd onto you and you just die.

IDK who the fuck thought this game needed a "fuck you" spawn for the basic solo player mode, but I went into 4 games and they were all the same. I was either completely surrounded, or I only had 1 direction I could go down and it was littered with skeletons  and the area was way too narrow to avoid any hits (not that you fucking can, even the bow skeleton I encountered never missed a shot, even if I had my weapon put away and was strafing around him).

It's extremely upsetting because this game was super unique to the genre, and was insanely fun and engaging. Now it just sucks. It's anti-fun. There's no rewarding feeling of getting through enemies, you're just sitting there thinking "holy fucking shit how much more do I have to do?"

“Hold the Line”? More like “Hand Over the Code.”

I have been around since Playtest 1. I have over 2000 hours logged between Steam, the old Blacksmith launcher, and everything in between. I have seen every stage of this so-called Early Access project, and after two years it is still the same broken mess it has always been.

Ironmace likes to act like the scrappy underdogs, but the truth is that SDF and the team rely on Unreal Marketplace assets and have shown very little actual creativity or direction. They have had years to build something meaningful, but instead we get seasonal shops, meaningless hotfixes, and threats to the community for finding bugs in new maps. That is literally what the community is supposed to do during an Early Access phase. Players try to help improve the game and they get treated like the enemy.

The gold farming problem is out of control and most of us would not be surprised if SDF had a hand in it considering how the economy always seems to break in ways that benefit them. The game already has a bad reputation after getting kicked off Steam for “borrowing” from Nexon, and yet here we are again with the same recycled systems, the same excuses, and barely 7000 players left online.

Every time they post “Hold the Line” I cannot help but laugh. Hold the line? More like Hand it over. Step away from development, let an actual development team take over, and maybe the game could return to what it once was back during Playtest 2.

At this point a couple of teenagers with basic coding knowledge could probably finish this game faster and better than Ironmace has managed in two years. This could have been something amazing, but now it is just a shell of what it used to be.
